result.execSummary:
The defendant Hunter L.W. Thornton was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: If revoked, defendant entitled to 2 days credit, subject to verification of the jail.

miscConds.notes: Any/all counseling as deemed necessary/appropriate by DOC.
Pursuant to sec.973.015, Wisconsin Statutes, upon successful completion of probation, defendants record to be expunged.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

records.addlTxt: 9:35 AM Defendant Hunter L.W. Thornton in court.  Attorney Mark Walter Frank in court for Hunter L.W. Thornton.  Attorney Curtis E Johnson in court for State of Wisconsin. State recites joint recommendation:  Ct 2: dismissed but read-in.  Ct 1:  W/H 2 years probation:  counseling as recommended by DOC; restitution, if determined; $443 + $20 cps + $100 dva; expungment if successful completion.  Court verbally reviews charges/penalties with the defendant. Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights form - colloquy given.  Defendant freely, willingly, knowledgeably and intelligently enters into the plea agreement and joint recommendation. Court accepts the joint recommendation and sentences the defendant accordingly.
